articles.headline: A Regulatory Rush by Federal Agencies to Secure Trump’s Legacy
articles.snippet: With the president’s re-election in doubt, cabinet departments are scrambling to finish dozens of new rules affecting millions of Americans.
articles.abstract: With the president’s re-election in doubt, cabinet departments are scrambling to finish dozens of new rules affecting millions of Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing the prospect that President Trump could lose his re-election bid, his cabinet is scrambling to enact regulatory changes affecting millions of Americans in a blitz so rushed it may leave some changes vulnerable to court challenges.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Who Was ‘El Padrino,’ Godfather to Drug Cartel? Mexico’s Defense Chief, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: Drug enforcement agents had long tried to solve the mystery of “El Padrino,” a shadowy, powerful force. They’ve now identified him as Salvador Cienfuegos, Mexico’s defense chief from 2012 to 2018.
articles.abstract: Drug enforcement agents had long tried to solve the mystery of “El Padrino,” a shadowy, powerful force. They’ve now identified him as Salvador Cienfuegos, Mexico’s defense chief from 2012 to 2018.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — American law enforcement agents were listening in as Mexican cartel members chattered on a wiretap, talking about a powerful, shadowy figure known as El Padrino, or The Godfather.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: In Reversal, Twitter Is No Longer Blocking New York Post Article
articles.snippet: The latest change underlined how rapidly social media platforms are shifting their positions in the days leading up to the election.
articles.abstract: The latest change underlined how rapidly social media platforms are shifting their positions in the days leading up to the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is the 11th hour before the presidential election. But Facebook and Twitter are still changing their minds.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: $421 Million in Debt: Trump Calls It ‘a Peanut,’ but Challenges Lie Ahead
articles.snippet: The president on Thursday played down big loans he guaranteed for his struggling businesses. But much of that debt is soon to come due in the midst of declining revenue and an I.R.S. audit that could cost him over $100 million.
articles.abstract: The president on Thursday played down big loans he guaranteed for his struggling businesses. But much of that debt is soon to come due in the midst of declining revenue and an I.R.S. audit that could cost him over $100 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump painted a rosy picture of his financial condition during a televised town hall on Thursday night, calling his hundreds of millions of dollars in debt coming due “a peanut” and saying he had borrowed it as a favor to lenders eager to take advantage of his financial strength.
articles.byline: By Russ Buettner and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Make Your First Home Your Last: The Case for Not Moving Up
articles.snippet: It’s a tough moment for big decisions. Think more about what you’ll want in three years — and not just three months, when we’ll still be shut in.
articles.abstract: It’s a tough moment for big decisions. Think more about what you’ll want in three years — and not just three months, when we’ll still be shut in.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home has become work and school for millions of people. Many residences needed to somehow shift overnight to accommodate two workplaces and multiple classrooms because of the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: ‘Please Like Me,’ Trump Begged. For Many Women, It’s Way Too Late.
articles.snippet: The white suburban voters the president needs to carve a path to victory have turned away from him, for deeply personal reasons.
articles.abstract: The white suburban voters the president needs to carve a path to victory have turned away from him, for deeply personal reasons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WESTERVILLE, Ohio — Kate Rabinovitch doesn’t call herself an activist.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: Joe Biden’s Non-Radical 1960s
articles.snippet: Trump has called Biden a tool of leftist agitators. Friends say that has never much been his way, even as a young man surrounded by protest.
articles.abstract: Trump has called Biden a tool of leftist agitators. Friends say that has never much been his way, even as a young man surrounded by protest.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our profile detailing Joe Biden’s road to the White House and presidency.]
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: Federal Appeals Courts Emerge as Crucial for Trump in Voting Cases
articles.snippet: Federal district courts have tended to rule for Democrats in litigation over how to run the election, but appeals courts, well stocked with the president’s nominees, are blocking them.
articles.abstract: Federal district courts have tended to rule for Democrats in litigation over how to run the election, but appeals courts, well stocked with the president’s nominees, are blocking them.
articles.lead_paragraph: This month, a federal judge struck down a decree from Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas limiting each county in the state to a single drop box to handle the surge in absentee ballots this election season, rejecting Mr. Abbott’s argument that the limit was necessary to combat fraud.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: ‘White Supremacy’ Once Meant David Duke and the Klan. Now It Refers to Much More.
articles.snippet: The phrase has poured into the nation’s rhetorical bloodstream. Organizations from the N.F.L. to art museums to colleges requiring the SAT are accused of perpetuating it.
articles.abstract: The phrase has poured into the nation’s rhetorical bloodstream. Organizations from the N.F.L. to art museums to colleges requiring the SAT are accused of perpetuating it.
articles.lead_paragraph: As July 4 and its barbecues arrived this year, the activist and former N.F.L. quarterback Colin Kaepernick declared, “We reject your celebration of white supremacy.”
articles.byline: By Michael Powell

articles.headline: As the Coronavirus Surges, a New Culprit Emerges: Pandemic Fatigue
articles.snippet: Exhaustion and impatience are creating new risks as cases soar in parts of the world. “They have had enough,” one U.S. mayor said of her residents.
articles.abstract: Exhaustion and impatience are creating new risks as cases soar in parts of the world. “They have had enough,” one U.S. mayor said of her residents.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Sarah Mervosh and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Flush With Cash, Biden Eclipses Trump in War for the Airwaves
articles.snippet: Joe Biden is vastly outspending President Trump in TV advertising, maintaining a nearly 2-to-1 advantage on the airwaves.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden is vastly outspending President Trump in TV advertising, maintaining a nearly 2-to-1 advantage on the airwaves.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joe Biden is vastly outspending President Trump in TV advertising, maintaining a nearly 2-to-1 advantage on the airwaves.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti, Weiyi Cai and Denise Lu

articles.headline: Why These Voters Rejected Hillary Clinton but Are Backing Joe Biden
articles.snippet: For many Democrats and independents who sat out 2016, voted for third-party candidates or backed Donald Trump, Mr. Biden is more acceptable to them in ways large and small than Mrs. Clinton was.
articles.abstract: For many Democrats and independents who sat out 2016, voted for third-party candidates or backed Donald Trump, Mr. Biden is more acceptable to them in ways large and small than Mrs. Clinton was.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samantha Kacmarik, a Latina college student in Las Vegas, said that four years ago, she had viewed Hillary Clinton as part of a corrupt political establishment.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Trump Runs the Kind of Campaign He Likes, but Not the One He Might Need
articles.snippet: With little time left to change the trajectory of the race, there is a large gulf separating the president’s experience of the campaign from the more sobering assessments of party officials.
articles.abstract: With little time left to change the trajectory of the race, there is a large gulf separating the president’s experience of the campaign from the more sobering assessments of party officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: In public, President Trump and his campaign team project a sense of optimism and bravado. When they meet with Republican donors and state party leaders, presidential aides insist they are fully capable of achieving a close victory over Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Nov. 3.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: At Front Lines of a Brutal War: Death and Despair in Nagorno-Karabakh
articles.snippet: Times journalists find civilians huddling in basements as a three-week-old conflict over the disputed Caucasus territory hints of a long and punishing fight.
articles.abstract: Times journalists find civilians huddling in basements as a three-week-old conflict over the disputed Caucasus territory hints of a long and punishing fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: STEPANAKERT, Nagorno-Karabakh — On the front line, the stench is overwhelming. The remains of fighters have been lying there for weeks.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Sergey Ponomarev

articles.headline: Remote but Inclusive for Years, and Now Showing Other Companies How
articles.snippet: Ultranauts has been developing creative ways to hire, manage and motivate a far-flung and diverse work force for seven years.
articles.abstract: Ultranauts has been developing creative ways to hire, manage and motivate a far-flung and diverse work force for seven years.
articles.lead_paragraph: From her home in Beaverton, Ore., Jamie Davila leads a team of eight engineers in seven states for the technology start-up Ultranauts. Like millions of other people during these work-from-home times, she relies on popular communication tools like Zoom and Slack.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr

articles.headline: As Local News Dies, a Pay-for-Play Network Rises in Its Place
articles.snippet: A nationwide operation of 1,300 local sites publishes coverage that is ordered up by Republican groups and corporate P.R. firms.
articles.abstract: A nationwide operation of 1,300 local sites publishes coverage that is ordered up by Republican groups and corporate P.R. firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: The instructions were clear: Write an article calling out Sara Gideon, a Democrat running for a hotly contested U.S. Senate seat in Maine, as a hypocrite.
articles.byline: By Davey Alba and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: New York Post Published Hunter Biden Report Amid Newsroom Doubts
articles.snippet: Some reporters withheld their bylines and questioned the credibility of an article that made the tabloid’s front page on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Some reporters withheld their bylines and questioned the credibility of an article that made the tabloid’s front page on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Post’s front-page article about Hunter Biden on Wednesday was written mostly by a staff reporter who refused to put his name on it, two Post employees said.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Donald Trump Is Losing His Touch. So Is the TV Producer Who Shaped His Image.
articles.snippet: Mark Burnett helped turn Donald Trump into a national figure with “The Apprentice.” But since 2016, his impact “has kind of gone bust.”
articles.abstract: Mark Burnett helped turn Donald Trump into a national figure with “The Apprentice.” But since 2016, his impact “has kind of gone bust.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Did you catch Steve Harvey’s “Funderdome” on ABC? How about “The World’s Best” on CBS, “The Contender” on Epix, or “World’s Toughest Race: Eco-Challenge” on Amazon Prime? Or the Christian-themed dramas “A.D. The Bible Continues” on NBC and “Messiah” on Netflix?
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: With Covid-19 Under Control, China’s Economy Surges Ahead
articles.snippet: Exports jumped and local governments engaged in a binge of debt-fueled construction projects. Even consumer spending is finally recovering.
articles.abstract: Exports jumped and local governments engaged in a binge of debt-fueled construction projects. Even consumer spending is finally recovering.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: An Earthquake, an Orphanage, and New Beginnings for Haitian Children in America
articles.snippet: After the 2010 earthquake in Haiti, 19 children from one orphanage were flown to the U.S. to be adopted by American families. One would later meet President Trump.
articles.abstract: After the 2010 earthquake in Haiti, 19 children from one orphanage were flown to the U.S. to be adopted by American families. One would later meet President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a devastating earthquake hit Haiti in 2010, a teenager named John Peter was playing basketball in the yard outside the small orphanage where he lived. He felt the earth bounce below him. He heard screams and watched a mushroom cloud of dust rising over the walls.
articles.byline: By Catherine Porter and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Mask Mandate? In a Montana Town, It ‘Puts Us at Odds With Customers’
articles.snippet: In Hamilton, business owners are walking a tightrope between keeping people safe from the coronavirus and not driving them away.
articles.abstract: In Hamilton, business owners are walking a tightrope between keeping people safe from the coronavirus and not driving them away.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMILTON, Mont. — Outside River Rising Bakery sits an older gentleman, his face uncovered. He’s here every morning, greeting customers as he drinks his coffee and reads. Inside, people mill about, waiting to order. A group of moms chat at a corner table.
articles.byline: By Amy Haimerl

articles.headline: After Teacher’s Decapitation, France Unleashes a Broad Crackdown on ‘the Enemy Within’
articles.snippet: With dozens of raids against Muslim individuals and groups accused of radicalism, the fury of the response had France’s right wing speaking in terms of warfare.
articles.abstract: With dozens of raids against Muslim individuals and groups accused of radicalism, the fury of the response had France’s right wing speaking in terms of warfare.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — France on Monday unleashed a broad crackdown on Muslims accused of extremism, carrying out dozens of raids, vowing to shut down aid groups and threatening to expel foreigners as anger swept the country following the decapitation of a middle school teacher for showing caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad in class.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Review 2 of Trump’s Major Immigration Policies
articles.snippet: The court adds to a docket of cases that will test the president’s agenda.
articles.abstract: The court adds to a docket of cases that will test the president’s agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to review two major Trump administration immigration initiatives, adding them to a docket now crowded with cases that will test President Trump’s agenda and policies.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Chasing Illicit Money, Global Officials Circle a Puerto Rican Firm
articles.snippet: Tax enforcers from five nations are investigating Euro Pacific Bank, which operates in a U.S. territory criticized in the past for its lax financial regulation.
articles.abstract: Tax enforcers from five nations are investigating Euro Pacific Bank, which operates in a U.S. territory criticized in the past for its lax financial regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tax authorities from the United States and four other countries have joined forces to stop shadowy global money networks that use international borders to stymie local investigations.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Damien Cave
